results.title: How should we remember Stuart?
results.creator_credit: Kath Ensor, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Speaking for her grandmother, Elizabeth, Kath Ensor remembers her grandfather, Stuart. Encompassing his time serving in the RAAF during World War II, his love for his family and his positive attitude, despite experiencing ill health.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kath Ensor, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Hidden treasure : thoughts about living with Turner's Syndrome : Digital Storytelling project
results.brief_description:
Turner’s Syndrome affects one in every 2000-2500 females. A genetic disorder due to the absence of an X chromosome, it usually leads to growth difficulties, infertility and, in some cases, learning difficulties, particularly with mathematics and spatial relationships.
These twelve stories are by those who have lived with Turner’s Syndrome, either by being diagnosed with it or caring for a child with the disorder. The inspiring stories are about living with Turner’s Syndrome and not letting it prevent them from living a normal life.
results.title_for_label: Hidden treasure : thoughts about living with Turner’s Syndrome : Digital Storytelling project
results.description:
Turner’s Syndrome affects one in every 2000-2500 females. A genetic disorder due to the absence of an X chromosome, it usually leads to growth difficulties, infertility and, in some cases, learning difficulties, particularly with mathematics and spatial relationships.
These twelve stories are by those who have lived with Turner’s Syndrome, either by being diagnosed with it or caring for a child with the disorder. The inspiring stories are about living with Turner’s Syndrome and not letting it prevent them from living a normal life.
description_for_label:
Turner’s Syndrome affects one in every 2000-2500 females. A genetic disorder due to the absence of an X chromosome, it usually leads to growth difficulties, infertility and, in some cases, learning difficulties, particularly with mathematics and spatial relationships.
These twelve stories are by those who have lived with Turner’s Syndrome, either by being diagnosed with it or caring for a child with the disorder. The inspiring stories are about living with Turner’s Syndrome and not letting it prevent them from living a normal life.

results.title: What a whirlwind relationship!
results.creator_credit: Lucy Pucci, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Two months into their relationship, Lucy Pucci told her partner that she has Turner’s Syndrome and won’t be able to have children. He stuck by her then, just as he has stuck by her through their various agonising attempts to have children of their own.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lucy Pucci, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Turning perceptions
results.creator_credit: Karlene Lynch, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Karlene Lynch found out when she was 21 that she had Turner’s Syndrome. Despite the agony of being infertile and the health difficulties, Lynch has led a happy and inspiring life.

results.title: Turner's Syndrome : trials and triumphs
results.creator_credit: Jackie Breasley, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Living with Turner’s Syndrome, Jackie Breasley has had to overcome many difficulties. As she grows up, she has faced much more heartbreaking challenges. Regardless, these challenges all present Breasley with opportunities to triumph.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jackie Breasley, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
